definitions.definition: large in size, degree, amount, etc.

examples.text: a big man/house/increase
This shirt isn't big enough.
It's the world's biggest computer company.
He had this **great big** grin on his face.
The lobster's claws are **bigger than** human hands.
The festival is **getting bigger** every year.
Her smile **grew bigger**.
They were earning big money.
The news came as a big blow.
He was a big man—tall and broad-shouldered.
He was a short man with great big glasses.
This house is rather big for us. We need something smaller.
There's been a big increase in prices.
We were hoping the show would be a really big success.
The whole story is just a big fat lie.

definitions.definition: older

examples.text: my big brother
You're a big girl now.

definitions.definition: important; serious

examples.text: It's a big decision to have to make.
You are making a big mistake.
Unemployment is a **big problem** in the region.
This legislation will make a **big difference**.
The **big question** is: why did they do it?
Housing is a **big issue** in London.
a potentially big drawback
She took the stage for her **big moment**.
It doesn't **get bigger** than the World Cup Final!
Tonight is the biggest match of his career.
Do you really think we can take on the **big boys** *(= compete with the most powerful people)*?

definitions.definition: needing a lot of effort, money or time to succeed

examples.text: They're full of big ideas.

definitions.definition: popular with the public; successful

examples.text: Orange is the big colour this year.
The band's very big in Japan.

definitions.definition: enthusiastic about somebody/something

examples.text: I'm a big fan of hers.

definitions.definition: doing something often or to a large degree

examples.text: a big eater/drinker/spender

definitions.definition: kind or generous

examples.text: He gave me an extra five pounds for two hours' work. I thought ‘That's big of you’.

definitions.definition: to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really are
an important and powerful person, especially in an organization
used to say that you are not impressed by something

examples.text: So he earns more than me. Big deal!

definitions.definition: the most important person or thing
an important person (in a small community)
an offensive term for a weak man, who is not brave or confident
the ability to keep moving ahead of your competitors, especially in politics

examples.text: In politics, momentum is known as the big mo.
He's picking up a lot of support and **has the big mo**.

definitions.definition: an important person
the situation as a whole

examples.text: Right now forget the details and take a look at the big picture.

definitions.definition: the use or threat of force or power

examples.text: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

definitions.definition: the three, four, etc. most important countries, people, companies, etc.

examples.text: She works for one of the Big Six.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to show your approval of somebody by clapping your hands; to be applauded in this way

examples.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let’s give a big hand to our special guests tonight.

definitions.definition: to have more important or more interesting things to do
to be bad at keeping secrets
to talk too much, especially about your own abilities and achievements
on a large/small scale

examples.text: The new delivery service has taken off in a big way.
Many people are investing in a small way in the stock market.
He then started spending money in a big way.

definitions.definition: to make something seem more important than it really is
used when you realize that you have said something that you should not have said
a person or thing that people think will be very popular or successful soon

examples.text: She has been talked up as the next big thing in British tennis.
Everyone is trying to guess what the next big thing in street fashion is going to be.

definitions.definition: used to say that something is not important or not a problem

examples.text: If I don't win it's no big deal.

definitions.definition: so important to the economy of a country that when it finds itself in financial trouble, the government or central bank must act to save it

examples.text: Shouldering the huge costs of rescuing banks that are too big to fail has been left to taxpayers.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘strong, mighty’): of unknown origin.
